{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3584505,"name":"Noah","username":"Noah01","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/b38774/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-08T23:35:02.555Z","cooked":"

Hello, I’m using the swerve modules with the YAGSL library to create my code, I would like to create buttons for my robot to align with the reef, my team doesn’t have the LL so I would like to use my robot’s agulation for the 6 points of the reef, which would already help a lot, does anyone know how I can do this, I thought the best would be a PID controller for the rotation until I get the necessary angle, has anyone done something similar that they can share???

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-04-08T23:35:02.555Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":139,"readers_count":138,"score":72.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":498510,"topic_slug":"swerve-autoalign","display_username":"Noah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73940,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-autoalign/498510/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3584525,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-08T23:44:37.925Z","cooked":"

The easiest way is to just take advantage of the fact that lamba syntax on Yagsl’s drive commands exist: You can just create a drive routine similar to the default one, but swapping the angular controller from ()->driverjoystick.axis(...) to ()->/*pid output for a target angle*/

However, getting the target angle might require some tricks. A lot of us using vision + odometry can auto-align based on absolute field positions, but sounds like you can’t. However, you can do clever things to make this happen. Here’s some ideas:

  • Give your drivers 6 buttons to align with, one for each reef facing angle.
  • Give your driver one button, which figures out what angle they’re facing, what the closest “reef angle” is, and then locks to it.
  • Have a button that makes the “rotation joystick” control the “facing angle”, then do the above, and lock the angle to one of 6 possible options according to the reef.

Our drive team would probably go with the second one, but every driver will have a different preference for this kind of thing.

I know about the odometer, but my team doesn’t have the cameras for vision, and I don’t know if I have the programming level for this, but I intend to create a first option, what is the best way to use the yaw pigeon for angle?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-04-08T23:50:35.695Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":29.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":498510,"topic_slug":"swerve-autoalign","display_username":"Noah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":44763,"username":"tekdemo","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73940,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-autoalign/498510/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3584894,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-09T06:55:08.185Z","cooked":"

Pigeon docs are your friend here. Unfortunately, I’ve never used one so I can’t help with details relating to the API or quirks related to mounting and re-orienting it.

We didn’t do this in Yagsl (we used other routines this year), but our code last year was pretty much this:
In robotcontainer, the code is pretty close to what Yagsl would request:

driverController.button(1)
.whileTrue(chassis.getDriveToBearingCommand(
()-> -driverController.getLeftY(), 
()-> -driverController.getLeftX(), 
()->Units.Degrees.of(180))); //Face toward driver

The only notable difference from what you’d do normally for driving is just replacing the driver’s rotation joystick with a PID routine that generates the output.

As for the actual PID implementation of that command, here’s where we had implemented that code in our bot. Pardon the mess, this code went through a few revisions.
https://github.com/stormbots/Crescendo/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Chassis.java#L415
